Range.summary: The Range interface represents a fragment of a document that can contain nodes and parts of text nodes.

remarks.para: A range can be created by using the method. Range objects can also be retrieved by using the method of the object or the method of the object.
There also is the constructor available.

RangeCloneContents.summary: The cloneContents() method of the interface copies the selected children of the range's and puts them in a new object.

remarks.para: Nodes are cloned using the same algorithm as , which means event listeners attached with scripts are not cloned. HTML id attributes are cloned, which can lead to an invalid document through cloning.

The first and last selected children of commonAncestorContainer may be partially selected. In this case, the child node itself is cloned, but its content is only the part that is selected, by recursively cloning the range between the original range's start/end boundary and that child node's end/start boundary.

RangeCloneRange.summary:
The Range.cloneRange() method returns a
object with boundary points identical to the cloned
.

remarks.para:
The returned clone is copied by value, not reference, so a change in either
does not affect the other.

RangeCollapse.summary:
The collapse() method of the interface collapses the
to one of its boundary points.

remarks.para:
A collapsed is empty, containing no content, specifying a
single-point in a DOM tree. To determine if a is already collapsed,
see the property.

RangeCommonAncestorContainer.summary:
The Range.commonAncestorContainer read-only property
returns the deepest — or furthest down the document tree — that
contains both boundary points of the . This means that if
and both refer to
the same node, this node is the common ancestor container.

remarks.para:
Since a Range need not be continuous, and may also partially select nodes,
this is a convenient way to find a Node which encloses a
Range.

This property is read-only. To change the ancestor container of a Node,
consider using the various methods available to set the start and end positions of the
Range, such as and
.

RangeCompareBoundaryPoints.summary: The compareBoundaryPoints() method of the interface compares the boundary points of the with those of another range.
RangeCompareBoundaryPoints.returns: A number.This API is consistent with the general convention that, when comparing A to B, a negative number means A comes before B and vice versa (see for example ). The ranges are compared in the direction of this to other, the same as . However, the boundary points are specified in the reverse order for the how parameter: END_TO_START compares the start of this to the end of other.

RangeCompareNode.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The compareNode() method of the interface returns a constant indicating the
position of the .
RangeCompareNode.returns: A constant indicating the position of the . The possible values are:

RangeComparePoint.summary: The comparePoint() method of the interface determines whether a specified point is before, within, or after the . The point is specified by a reference node and an offset within that node.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThis method parses its input as HTML or XML, writing the result into a that might subsequently be injected into the DOM.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks, if the input originally came from an attacker.

remarks.para:
You can reduce the risk by assigning objects instead of strings, and enforcing trusted types using the require-trusted-types-for CSP directive.
This ensures that the input is passed through a transformation function, which has the chance to sanitize the input to remove potentially dangerous markup, such as script elements and event handler attributes.
The Range.createContextualFragment() method of the interface returns a representing the parsed input HTML or XML.

RangeDeleteContents.summary: The Range.deleteContents() method removes all completely-selected {{ domxref("Node", "nodes", "", "nocode") }} within this range from the document. For the partially selected nodes at the start or end of the range, only the selected portion of the text is deleted, while the node itself remains intact. Afterwards, the range is collapsed to the end of the last selected node.

remarks.para: Unlike , this method does not return a containing the deleted content.

RangeDetach.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The Range.detach() method does nothing. It used to
disable the object and enable the browser to release associated
resources. The method has been kept for compatibility.

RangeExtractContents.summary: The extractContents() method of the interface is similar to a combination of and . It removes the child s of the range from the document, clones them, and returns them as a new object. For partially selected nodes, only the selected text is deleted, but all containing parent nodes up to the common ancestor are cloned as well, resulting in two copies of these nodes, one in the original document and one in the extracted fragment.

RangeGetBoundingClientRect.summary:
The Range.getBoundingClientRect() method returns a object that bounds the contents of the range; this is a rectangle
enclosing the union of the bounding rectangles for all the elements in the range.

remarks.para:
This method is useful for determining the viewport coordinates of the cursor or
selection inside a text box. See for
details on the returned value.

- - finer-grained result for non-rectangular
ranges (e.g., when the selection wraps onto the next line);
-
- - to get the (node, offset) from
viewport coordinates.

RangeGetBoundingClientRect.returns: A object that encloses the union of the bounding rectangles for all elements in the range.

RangeGetClientRects.summary:
The Range.getClientRects() method returns a list of objects representing the area of the screen occupied by the range. This is created by aggregating the results of calls to
for all the elements in the range.

RangeInsertNode.summary:
The Range.insertNode() method inserts a node at the start
of the .

remarks.para:
The new node is inserted at the start boundary point of the Range. If the
new node is to be added to a text , that Node is split
at the insertion point, and the insertion occurs between the two text nodes.

If the new node is a document fragment, the children of the document fragment are
inserted instead.

RangeIntersectsNode.summary:
The Range.intersectsNode() method returns a boolean
indicating whether the given intersects the .

RangeIsPointInRange.summary: The isPointInRange() method of the interface determines whether a specified point is within the . The point is specified by a reference node and an offset within that node. It is equivalent to calling and checking if the result is 0.

RangeRange.summary:
The Range() constructor returns a newly created
object whose start and end are offset 0 of the global
object.

remarks.para:
-The DOM interfaces index
-
-CSS custom highlight API module

RangeSelectNode.summary:
The Range.selectNode() method sets the
to contain the and its contents. The parent
of the start and end of the will be the same as
the parent of the referenceNode.

RangeSelectNodeContents.summary: The Range.selectNodeContents() method sets the to contain the contents of a .

remarks.para:
The parent Node of the start and end of the Range will be the
reference node. The startOffset is 0, and the endOffset is the
number of child Nodes or number of characters contained in the reference
node.

RangeSetEnd.summary:
The Range.setEnd() method sets the end position of a to be located at the given offset into the specified node. Setting
the end point above (higher in the document) than the start point will result in a
collapsed range with the start and end points both set to the specified end position.

RangeSetEndAfter.summary:
The Range.setEndAfter() method sets the end position of a
relative to another . The parent
Node of end of the Range will be the same as that for the
referenceNode.

RangeSetEndBefore.summary:
The Range.setEndBefore() method sets the end position of
a Range relative to another . The parent
Node of end of the Range will be the same as that for the
referenceNode.

RangeSetStart.summary:
The Range.setStart() method sets the start position of a
.

remarks.para:
If the startNode is a of type ,
, or , then startOffset is
the number of characters from the start of startNode. For other
Node types, startOffset is the number of child nodes between
the start of the startNode.

Setting the start point below (lower in the document) the end point will result in a
collapsed range with the start and end points both set to the specified start position.

RangeSetStartAfter.summary:
The Range.setStartAfter() method sets the start position
of a relative to a . The parent
of the start of the will be the same as that
for the referenceNode.

RangeSetStartBefore.summary:
The Range.setStartBefore() method sets the start position
of a relative to another . The parent
of the start of the will be the same as that
for the referenceNode.

RangeSurroundContents.summary: The surroundContents() method of the interface surrounds the selected content by a provided node. It extracts the contents of the range, replaces the children of newParent with the extracted contents, inserts newParent at the location of the extracted contents, and makes the range select newParent.

remarks.para: An exception is thrown if the range partially contains any non- node. The range must only contain text nodes and completely selected nodes.

RangeToString.summary:
The Range.toString() method is a stringifier returning
the text of the .
